videos.title: The Fastest & Weirdest Gravel Bike Setups Pros Are Using in 2025
videos.description:
Some insights from the pros and amateurs racing the Traka gravel race in Girona recently on the tech trends that are hot right now, from aero everywhere to wide tyres and yet more mountain bike influence. 

Content
00:00 Intro
1:02 Aero gravel is hot right now
3:09 Wide tyres are massive
6:17 1x gearing is very popular
9:07 Hydration packs
10:46 Suspension forks???

videos.transcript:
Right. Hello viewers. Now, what are the
best and worst gravel bike tech trends
in
2025? Well, to find out, I went along to
Europe's biggest gravel race, the Trackr
in Jerona, just outside of Barcelona in
Spain, to discover what the tech trends
are right now. And I spoke to a load of
people over the finish line. And in this
video, I'll share five tech trends that
stood out for me. And what I love about
gravel racing right now and gravel
generally is there are no rules. And
it's a real wild west of bike setups.
And that means there's a real myriad of
bike setups. And it's fun to see how
riders approach the same race from
different approaches based on their
different backgrounds, whether a
mountain biker or a roadie or elsewhere.
And every rider will no doubt tell you
they have the best setup, but they can't
all have the best setup, can they? So,
let me know what you think of the tech
trends and setups in the comment section
below. Firstly, arrow is everywhere.
I've never seen so many arrow socks in
my life. It's like a road race on dirt.
So arrow is clearly very important not
just in road racing where the speeds are
higher but even in gravel where the
speeds are yes lower but arrow is still
important which is kind of funny when
you remember back to 2016 when 3T
launched the exploro and everybody
thought the idea of aerero gravel was
crazy and they laughed at that bike but
that's not the case anymore who's
laughing now because arrow is everywhere
socks. I never seen so many aeros socks
in my life. Skin suits of course and
arrow helmets. So those are three main
sort of onbody tech trends I saw. And
speeds on gravel may not be as high as
they are on the road, but they're still
going fast enough. The pros anyway,
still going fast enough, well over 15
mph where arrow really matters for arrow
to be that important. So minimizing the
drag on the body with the full outfit of
Arrow kit. The other obvious aeros setup
was narrow handlebars and angled in
hoods which Dylan Johnson as you know is
a proponent and you see his video bike
check linked above and down below in
case you missed it. So quite a few bikes
with very narrow handlebars but not as
many as I would have thought. Most
riders had sort of 38 to 40 cm flared
drop handlebars and there were quite a
few on extremely narrow handlebars, but
most riders seem to have a fairly normal
setup because while narrow in terms of
handlebar width is more arrow on gravel
when you're riding off-road, especially
a very technical hardcore course like
Trackr. It's that balance of arrow on
the flatter sections, but also handling
agility and stability when descending
through corners and single track. And
narrow handlebars in my experience just
don't handle through the corners as well
as a wider handlebar. So yeah, narrow
handlebars not as common as I might have
thought because of that tradeoff with
handling and getting through corners and
stuff. The other obvious tech trend is
wide tires. tires are getting wider. And
in my 10 plus years of riding and
testing gravel bikes, tires have
consistently been getting wider and
wider. And it's just the same as I
experienced in mountain biking back in
the '9s and the 2000s from 1.5 to 1.9 in
tires to now 2.4 and 2.6 in tires with a
brief outlier to 2.8 and 3 in wide tires
which prove that wider isn't always
better. So there is a limit to how wide
you can go. But at Trackr, wide tires
were definitely an obvious tech trend
and quite a few people I spoke to were
running 50 mm wide tires. So proving
that 50 might be a new 45. I've been
running 45 for the last few years quite
happily, but now running 47 and 50 and
that seems like the new sort of
standard, but that does raise obvious
clearance issues with bikes not designed
around such wide tires. And the avid
trend is of course mountain bike tires.
Again, Dylan Johnson is a fan of
mountain bike tires. Done some really
interesting testing that shows the
benefits of mountain bike tires. And
quite a few riders had mountain bike
tires on their bikes. So, a real mix of
15 mil wide gravel tires and two or 2.1
or 2.2 in mountain bike tires as well.
But tire size is definitely limited by
the clearance on the bike. And there
were some riders I saw with bike setups
that clearly sacrificed clearance on a
level I would not be happy with at all.
And given the mud we encountered on a
Sunday in a 100k race, which was filthy
biblical rain, it's clearance that would
just cause issues in terms of mud and
stone getting caught between the wheel
and tire and a bike grinding to a halt.
And that's a real balance and compromise
with tie sizes is how much clearance
your bike has and how much clearance
between the frame and rubber you are
prepared to have. And there are actual
official guidelines that bike
manufacturers have to follow for safety
reasons. And most riders push beyond
those limits if they're happy to
compromise or sacrifice tire clearance.
The other tech trend I saw is mixed tire
sizes, which is the same as in mountain
biking. If you mountain bike, you know
that generally you have a chunkier,
wider, stickier directional front tire
for cornering grip and precision and
usually a faster rolling narrower rear
tire. And we're now starting to see that
on gravel bikes as well. And to be
honest with you, I'm surprised it's
taken so long. And it's probably to do
with the road riding influence where you
have the same side tires front and rear
unless you go for arrow and they have a
narrow front tire. That's very rare
indeed. So quite a lot of bikes with a
mountain bike tire up front. So 2.1
something like that and then a smaller
45 or 50 mil faster rolling tread on the
back. So that's a trend I'm seeing
becoming a lot more common and one I'm
going to try on my own testing very very
soon. The other tech trend is around
gearing choice which is down to personal
preference of course two by or versus
one by to have or not have a front mech.
And while this is no conclusive uh
survey, I think most riders and most
bikes had one by gearing at
tracker. And of those bikes, most were
Stram and lots were either their Explore
gearing with a 1046 cassette on the back
and a 46 or 48 chambering on the front,
which is just massive for the climbing
on the track of course. But then quite a
few riders went to a mullet setup. So
using a mountain bike cassette and rear
mech with a 1052 cassette, then pairing
that also with a big chambering as well.
And quite a few riders I spoke to on the
finish line of the race admitted they
were overgeeared. They didn't have the
low enough gears they needed for the
steep lines on the course. And gearing
setup is all about gear range. And I
spoke to a lot of riders on the finish
line who readily admitted they were
overgeeared. Didn't have the low enough
gears they needed for the climbs on the
the brutal tracking course. And that is
a really important point. It's all very
well having a big massive chambering
that looks very imposing, but you need
the gears that actually allow you to
climb up the steep climbs. When the
climbs like on the track are steep and
long, you lose more time than you might
gain on a flat or descent by having a
big chain ring. So, it really comes down
to having or doing your research on the
course if you are racing and knowing the
elevation on that route and how steep
the gradient of the climbs are and
gearing your bike in an appropriate
manner and giving your bike the gears
you need to allow you to spin up the
climbs and not grind at 50 RPM. On the
one by versus two by I rode the Tracker
100 on a two by setup. Shimano
GRXD2 and I was both undergeeared on a
steep climbs thanks to that gear setup
and also in the conditions which were
awful. Managing the front Meg on the
course going up and down was a real pain
in the ass. And having one by is just
simpler. One less thing to worry about
when you come into a sudden climb got to
dump a load of gears. And the other
issue I had was the conditions were so
awful that the front shifting as good as
Shimano is wasn't that reliable and
chains was a common issue throughout my
race. So yeah, one buy in no conditions
just simpler and also much bigger range
available as well. So yeah, one by I
think is winning the battle for gravel
racing in 2025 based on my experience.
Not saying two by is redundant. There is
a time and place for two by, but for me
racing the tracker, one by is the way
forward. The other tech trend is
hydration packs. A big bladder of water
in your backpack with a hose to drink on
a move because in a gravel race, you are
really trying to minimize how much time
you stop. There are fee stations, but if
you stop, fill your bottle up, you're
losing time and you've been dropped from
that pack, that group you might be in.
And if you're very lucky, you might have
helpers, friends, and family holding up
water bottles at convenient places
around the race. But if you're riding
solo on your own, then you need to
minimize how much time you stop. And
lots of riders are now using a
combination of water bottles on their
bikes and a hydration bladder. And my
approach, my personal approach was to
copy the pros and had two bottles of
energy drink, high carb mix in the
bottles on the frame and then one liter
of water in the backpack. So I had a mix
of energy from my bottles, my gels in my
pockets on the hydration chest straps
and then water in the back for that sort
of mix of water and energy. So,
hydration packs, something I thought I
left behind in mountain biking in the
2000s and moved to water bottles on a
bike, are back in fashion. And we have
lots of lightweight options on the
market from lots of brands. I'll put
links to some down below that offer a
lightweight solution for carrying water
on your body. And I trying a new one
that isn't available yet, coming out
very soon. And I found it very comfy,
actually. It wasn't heavy. I have one
liter of water, all my gels in my
pockets here, and it is comfy. Yes, I
did sweat more through my back, but
that's a trade-off for carrying water on
your body. The avid tech trend, and this
is the most controversial, so I save it
till last, is suspension on gravel
bikes. Suspension 2.0, you might call
it. Suspension forks on gravel bikes.
Nothing new. We had the Fox AX many,
many years ago, and the Rock Shot Rudy.
And I've said in previous videos here on
Just Ride Bikes that I think suspension
on a gravel bike is a fantastic thing.
Suspension with big tires is a great
combo and better than just big tires on
their own because suspension forks had
damping. It's controlled and even though
it's only 40 or 50 mil of travel, it
still makes a big difference on rough
rocky terrain if you're riding at speed.
So you can ride faster and there's more
comfort as well and less fatigue through
your upper body. And while gravel has
yet to catch on, Canyon were showing a
new suspension fork on a Grail, a DT
Swiss engineer suspension fork with 40
mil travel on what appears to be a new
Grail. And I was actually riding the
bike in a tracker, but due to embargos,
I can't talk about the bike at all.
Sorry guys, but my experience of riding
that bike with that suspension fork is,
yeah, it's a game changer. It really is
fantastic. Suspension and big tires work
together brilliantly. And while 40 mil
of travel might not sound like much, it
makes a massive difference when you're
riding over washboard gravel. You're
dropping down a rocky descent. The roots
and rocks, it's both faster in those
situations. You're more control, so it's
safer and there's less fatigue. And my
body felt fresh as could be expected
after a 4hour race. My arms, my wrists
felt fine. My lower back, not so much.
So, suspension on gravel, yes, I know it
works. It still works. But whether it
catches on, it's another matter. I think
that's because most people come to
gravel racing are clearly coming from
road racing as a background where they
are weight obsessed. But if you're
coming from mountain biking, you'll know
as I do that suspension front and or
rear makes a massive difference. faster,
smoother, more control. So that's why I
don't think suspension on a gravel bike
will ever really catch on in a
meaningful way because that roady
background that most people bring to it.
They're more worried about weight even
though we all know really that weight
doesn't really matter at all. Arrow and
and comfort and compliance and
smoothness are more important. So yes,
that's suspension fork. Fantastic. Can't
wait to tell you more about it very very
soon. So, that is a a small tech trend,
but I spoke to Freddy Overt, a gravel
pro with Canyon, and he said gravel
suspension for him is a gamecher. His
words, not mine. Because his reasoning
for saying that is he's a roadie,
doesn't have amazing technical bike
handling skills, and often on a
technical descent, he's being dropped by
his peers. But now with a suspension
fork, he said it's raised him up from
back of the pack to near the front. It's
a skills compensator in a way. It's
given him the ability to keep up with
his peers who were dropping him before
on technical high-speed segments. So
that is yeah, that sounds like a valid
reason to go for suspension. So some
really interesting tech trends from the
tracker from Europe's biggest gravel
race. Arrow is everywhere. Suspension
isn't everywhere yet. What do you think
of these five tech trends? Which do you
think are hot? Which are not? Let me
know by dropping a comment down below.
And of course, let me know what gravel
race you have planned. I'm going to
Growlic at the weekend. If you're there,
I'll see you there. But that's all for
today. Thank you so much for watching.
I'll see you again very soon.

videos.title: Coast to Coast - 100mi (Gravel Race) 2024
videos.description:
👉 Hey! SUBSCRIBE for free WATTS 👉 https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsr-SU_SAqjrzmu4kXIRfUQ?sub_confirmation=1

*** 4th Overall and 1st in Age Group! ***

This was my first year doing this event and I was riding the course blind having not pre-road any of the sections. For a first timer what an epic 100 mile race on the bike through a complete downpour for most of it!  At least we got lucky with no rain for the first hour and half or so, then the heavens opened up. The back roads were treacherous with big puddles, huge rain ruts and deep soft sand. The conditions took a toll on my drivetrain as you can hear it get worse and worse as the hours went on. I had virtually no brakes and was metal on metal with no pads left. At the end my wheels would barely even spin in the frame! 

The race started pretty chill and one rider got off the front early. He was the eventual winner and no one was interested in chasing him down. My legs didn't feel great early on as they were still recovering from the Lumberjack 100 (100 mile MTB race) the previous weekend. For the first 2 hours of the race a few attacks went off the front but were all brought back. Just after 2 hours I dropped my chain for the first time 02:05:35. It took me a hard 7 minute effort to chase on but fortunately I was able to get back to the front group. Then just 10 minutes later I dropped my chain again, F*ck! 02:16:35

This second chase back was significantly harder both mentally and physically. There must have been attacks at the front as they were much further ahead. I didn't have much left after my first chase back, so I just tried to stay steady and hope that I'd eventually catch a group. I started picking up straggler that had fallen off the lead group and/or had mechanicals. Eventually after 20+ minutes I found the front group 02:38:05. I couldn't believe I'd actually made it back to the front twice! However, the group was a bit thinner as 2 more riders had already gotten off the front by the time I got back. So now there were 3 riders somewhere off the front, but nowhere in sight and our group was now the front chase group. I say "chase group" but no one, self included, was interested in truly chasing down these 3 front riders. We were all just in survival mode due to the conditions.

Our chase group of about 15 riders mostly all stayed together until BigM around mile 65. This is where most stopped for support grabbing water and food. I had brought everything with me to start,  so I just continued onto the singletrack climbs. A few other riders came with me and my goal was to just casually do the climbs and let the group eventually catch back on. This is where the conditions were the worse though. Midway through the trails I ended up dropping my chain for a 3rd time! I was passed by 3 riders and at that time sitting in 7th place overall 03:32:55.

I was able to get going quickly having now become an expert at fixing my chain issues. I slowly started passing the riders that passed me and I unintentionally separated myself. I felt quite comfortable bombing the sketchy downhills and had plenty of energy left to climb at a respectable pace. Apparently I was alone in those feelings because I kept gapping the others.  I came out of the BigM back roads alone with about a minute gap or so. I could see a rider or two in the distance behind me so I sat up and slow pedaled waiting for them to catch up. However, they never did and I couldn't understand why.

I had no intention of finishing the remaining 30+ miles for 2 hours alone in a torrential downpour. Not to mention my bike had become ridiculously crunchy and loud barely dragging itself forward. With no one in sight ahead of me to chase and losing any sight of those from behind, I continued at a reasonable pace waiting to be caught so we could work together to the finish. I must have looked back a 100 times waiting to see someone, but I never did. With about 10 miles or so remaining I decided to just go ahead to the finish line and get out of this damn weather. 

No one was surprised more than I when I found out I finished 4th overall and 1st in my age group! Super happy with the very unexpected results! 

***My front camera gave up and quit just over an hour into the race, but my rear camera held strong. The rear camera does however provide a different perspective of the group behind as I tried to stay near the front of the pack. I labeled the key moments (Lead Group, Chase, etc.) to provide context.***

***Crashes at 00:56:01 and 03:41:55.***
